translated: Shri. Vishvaprakash, composed by the learned and venerable Maheshavara.

analyzed: namaḥ samyaksambuddhāya
translated: Salutations to the Perfectly Enlightened One.

analyzed: stuvīmahi mahā moha kleśa anta kabhipaj varam
translated: We shall praise the excellent one who puts an end to the great delusion and afflictions,

analyzed: traidhātuka nidāna jña sarvajña duḥkha hānaye
translated: The knower of the root of the three realms, the omniscient one, for the destruction of suffering.

analyzed: kalā vilāsāt makaranda bindu mudrā vinidre hṛdaya arabinde
translated: The drop of honey from the play of arts, the seal of the sleeping lotus in the heart,

original: yā kalpayantī ramate kavīnā devī namasyāmi sarasvatī tām // //🔽kavīndrakumudānandakandodgapasudhākaram //🔽vācaspatimatisparddhiśemuṣīcandrikojjvalam // //
analyzed: yā kalpayantī ramate kavīnā devī namasyāmi sarasvatī tām
translated: Which delights in creating, I pay homage to that goddess Saraswati, the muse of poets.🔽The moon that rises from the nectar-like bulb of joy for the lilies of great poets,🔽Shining with the moonlight of the intellect that rivals the lord of speech,

analyzed: kṣubhyat kṣīrābdhi kallola mālā ullāsi yaśaḥ śriyam
translated: Whose fame and glory rise like a garland of waves from the churning ocean of milk,

original: guru vande jagadvandya guṇaratnaikarohaṇam // //🔽śrīsāhasāṅkanṛpateranavadyavaidya vodyātaraṅgapadamadvayameva bibhrit //
analyzed: guru vande jagat vandya guṇa ratna eka rohaṇam  śrī sāhasāṅka nṛpateḥ anavadya vaidya vā udyā taraṅga padam advayam eva bibhrit
translated: I pay homage to the guru, the mountain of jewels of virtues, who is worshipped by the world.🔽The king of Saahasa, who bears the incomparable stage of the waves of the unblemished medicine,

analyzed: yaḥ candracārucaritaḥ haricandra nāmā sva vyākhyāyā caraka tantram alañcakāra
translated: And who, with the name Harichandra, whose conduct is as charming as the moon, adorned the Caraka treatise with his own commentary.

analyzed: āsīt asīma vasudhādhipa vandanīye tasya anvaye sakala vaidya kalā vatasaḥ
translated: In his lineage, which is worthy of being worshipped by the kings of the limitless earth, was born one who mastered all the arts of medicine,

original: śakrasya dasra iva gādhipurādhipasya śrīkṛṣṇa ityamalakīrttilatāvitānaḥ // //
analyzed: śakrasya dasraḥ iva gādhipura adhipasya śrī kṛṣṇaḥ iti amala kīrtti latā vitānaḥ
translated: Like Indra and the Ashvins to the lord of the waters and the lord of the city, he is the canopy of the creeper of pure fame named Krishna.
The river of a thousand disputants agitated by the fire of argument, born of the thought of desire, with many alternatives.

analyzed: tarka traya trinayanaḥ tanayaḥ yadīyaḥ dāmodaraḥ vareṇyaḥ  /
translated: The son of the three-eyed one with three arguments, Damodara, is to be worshipped by the wise.

analyzed: tasya abhavat mūnaḥ udāra vācaḥ vācaspati śrī lalanā vilāsī
translated: He had a brother named Munirudara, who was a companion of the beautiful lady of the glory of Brihaspati.
The sun to the lotus of the knowledge of good medicine, the moon to the white water lily of the illustrious Madana.

original: yadbhrātṛjaḥ sakalavaidyakatattvaratna ratnākaraśriyamavāpya ca keśavo'bhūt //🔽kīrtterniketanamanindyapadapramāṇa vākyaprapañcaracanācaturāgananaśrī // //🔽kṛṣṇasya cā'jani sutaḥ sminapuṇḍarīka paṇḍātapatraparabhāgayaśaḥparāgaḥ //
analyzed: yad bhrātṛ jaḥ sakala vaidyaka tattva ratna ratnākara śriyam avāpya ca  kīrtteḥ niketanam anindya pada pramāṇa vākya prapañca racanā catur āganana śrī   / kṛṣṇasya ca ajani sutaḥ sminapuṇḍarīka paṇḍāta patra parabhāga yaśaḥ parāgaḥ
translated: Whose nephew Keshava obtained the glory of the ocean of jewels, the essence of all medicine,

original: tasyātmajaḥ sarasakairavakāntakīrtiḥ śrīmānmaheśvara iti prathitaḥ kavīndraḥ //
analyzed: tasya ātmajaḥ sarasa kairava kānta kīrtiḥ śrīmān maheśvaraḥ iti prathitaḥ kavi indraḥ
translated: His son, the great poet Maheshvara, whose fame is as sweet as the fresh lotus, is prosperous.

analyzed: niḥśeṣa vāc bhaya mahā arṇaca pāra dṛśvā śabda āgama amburuha paṇḍa raviḥ vabhūva  /
translated: He, who is the sun that has blossomed the lotus of the Vedic scriptures, is the one who has seen through the great ocean of language without exception.

analyzed: yaḥ sāhasāṅkacarita ādi mahā pravandha nirmmāṇa naipuṇa guṇa āgata gaurava śrīḥ
translated: He, who has attained the glory of the excellence of skill in composing the great work on the deeds of King Sāhasāṅka,

analyzed: yaḥ vaidyaka traya saroja saroja bandhu rbandhuḥ satā su kavi kairava kānana indu
translated: He, who is the friend of the lotus of the three medical treatises, is the friend of the good people, the moon in the forest of good poets.

original: iya kṛtistasya maheśvarasya vaidagdhyasindhoḥ puruṣottaānām //🔽dedīpyatā hṛtkamaleṣu nitya mākalpamākalpitakaustubhakṣīḥ // //
analyzed: iya kṛtiḥ tasya maheśvarasya vaidagdhya sindhoḥ puruṣottaānām  dedīpyatā hṛd kamaleṣu nitya mā ākalpam ākalpita kaustubha kṣīḥ
translated: This is the work of that Maheshvara, the ocean of skill, the best of men.🔽May he, who is always worshipped in the lotus of the heart, who wears the Kaustubha jewel, be radiant.

analyzed: labdhaiḥ kathañcid ābhijātasuvarṇakāra līlena koṣa vara ratna dhi śabdaratnaiḥ
translated: With the gems obtained somehow, by the playful best jeweler,

original: viśvaprakāśa iti kāñcanabandhaśobhā vibhranmayā'tra ghaṭito mukhakhaṇḍa epaḥ // //
analyzed: viśva prakāśaḥ iti kāñcana bandha śobhā vibhran mayā atra ghaṭitaḥ mukha khaṇḍaḥ epaḥ
translated: I have composed this Mukha-khanda here, bearing the beauty of the golden bondage called Vishva-prakasa.

analyzed: kṣoṇīśvara udīrita śabda koṣa rata ākara āloḍana lālasānām
translated: For those who are eager to churn the ocean of the treasury of words uttered by the king of the earth,

original: sevyaḥ katha naipa suvarṇaśailo viśvaprakāśo vibudhādhipānām // //
analyzed: sevyaḥ katha nā epa suvarṇa śailaḥ viśva prakāśaḥ vibudha adhipānām
translated: The golden mountain Vishva-prakasa of the lords of the gods should be served.

analyzed: bhogi indra kātyāyana sāhasāṅka vācaspati vyāḍi puraḥsarāṇām  śubha aṅga gopālita bhāgurāṇām
translated: of Bhogindra, Katyayana, Saahasa, Vachaspati, Vyadi, and others,🔽of Vishvarupa, Amala, Mangala, Shubha, Anga, Gopala, and Bhagura,

analyzed: koṣa avakāśāt prakaṭa prabhāva sambhāvita anardhya guṇaḥ saḥ epaḥ
translated: whose qualities are beyond price, whose glory is manifest from the treasury,

original: sampādayanneṣyati vāñchitārthāna katha na cintāmaṇinā kavīnām // //
analyzed: sampādayan eṣyati katha na cintāmaṇinā kavīnām
translated: fulfilling the desired objects, will he not be the wish-fulfilling gem of poets?

analyzed: ā mitraśaila carama acalam ekala adri kailāsa bhūmi valayāt yat iha asti kiñcid
translated: If there is anything here from the single mountain Kailash, which moves with its friends and mountains, up to the region of the earth,

original: ekatra sambhṛtamagocaraśabdaratna mālokyatā tadakhila sudhiyaḥ kavīndrāḥ // //
analyzed: ekatra sambhṛtam agocara śabda ratna sudhiyaḥ kavi indrāḥ
translated: may all the wise and great poets behold that collection of words and jewels in one place, O you of pure intellects!

original: yadyasti vāṅmayamahārṇavamanthanecchā prāptu pada phaṇipateryadi kautuka vaḥ //
analyzed: yadi asti vāc maya mahā arṇava manthana icchā prāptu pada phaṇi pateḥ yadi kautuka vaḥ
translated: If you have a desire to churn the great ocean of literature, and if you have a curiosity to obtain the position of the lord of serpents,

analyzed: viśva prakāśam aniśa tat ima niṣevya sambhāvya tā parama śābdika śesvara śrīḥ
translated: then, having always resorted to this universal illumination, may the glory of the supreme master of words be realized.

analyzed: satā pustaka sambhāra bhāra mokṣaḥ kṛtaḥ mayā
translated: I have released the burden of collecting good books.

analyzed: nāma anuśāsanam ida tanvatā adbhutam
translated: This treatise on names is completed by me in a wonderful way.

analyzed: eka dvi tri catur pañca ṣaṣ varṇa anukrama ujjvalaiḥ
translated: Shining with the sequence of one, two, three, four, five, and six letters,

analyzed: kāntā ādi vargaiḥ nānā artha saṅgrahaḥ vitanyate
translated: This collection of various meanings is being spread out by the group of beloveds and others.

analyzed: nānā arthaḥ prathamā antaḥ utra sarvatra ādau pradarśitaḥ
translated: The word nānārtha ending with the first case is shown everywhere at the beginning here.

analyzed: saptamī anteṣu śabdeṣu vartamānaḥ su niścitaḥ
translated: When used with words ending in the seventh case, it is ascertained well.

original: dṛṣṭāntena saha kkā'pi saptamyādhāra eva ca //
analyzed: dṛṣṭāntena saha kkāpi saptamyā ādhāraḥ eva ca
translated: Wherever there is a simile, the seventh case is the basis.

analyzed: spaṣṭāya liṅga bhedāya kkā api atra punarukta tā
translated: For the sake of the clear distinction of genders, there is repetition here again.

analyzed: kaikakam
translated: Ka (one)

analyzed: kaḥ brahma ātma anila arkeṣu śamane sarvanāmni ca
translated: Ka is used for Brahma, the self, wind, sun, peace, all names,

original: pāvake ca mayūre ca sukhaśīrṣajaleṣu kam // //
analyzed: pāvake ca mayūre ca sukha śīrṣa jaleṣu kam
translated: fire, peacock, and in sukhasiras (head of happiness) and jala (water).

analyzed: ka dvikam
translated: Ka (two)

original: aka pāpe ca duḥkhe ca śako rājanyadeśayoḥ //🔽vakastu vakapuṣpe syāt kadhe śrīde ca rakṣasi // //🔽śuko vyāsasute kīre rāvaṇasya ca mantriṇi //
analyzed: pāpe ca duḥkhe ca śakaḥ rājanya deśayoḥ  vakaḥ tu vakapuṣpe syāt kadhe śrīde ca rakṣasi  śukaḥ vyāsa sute kīre rāvaṇasya ca mantriṇi
translated: Aka means sin, misery, and shaka means a king and a country.🔽Vaka means a heron and a flower, kadhe means wealth, and rakhasi means a demoness.🔽Shuka means Vyasa's son, a sparrow, and Ravana's minister.

original: granthiparṇe śirīṣe ca śuka syācchoṇake kkacit // //🔽dvikaḥ kāke ca koke ca sṛo bāṇānilotpale //
analyzed: granthiparṇe śirīṣe ca syāt śoṇake kkacid  dvikaḥ kāke ca koke ca sṛḥ bāṇa anila utpale
translated: Shuka means a knot-leaf, a Shirisha tree, and sometimes a red one.🔽Sru (two) means a crow, a cuckoo, an arrow, wind, and a blue lotus.

analyzed: arka urka parṇe sphaṭike ravau tāmre divaspatau
translated: Arka means a sun-leaf, crystal, the sun, copper, and the lord of the day.

original: karkaḥ karke rāśibhede śuklāśve darpaṇe ghaṭe //
analyzed: karkaḥ karke rāśi bhede śuklāśve darpaṇe ghaṭe
translated: Karka means a crab, a zodiac sign, a white horse, a mirror, and a pot.

analyzed: tarkaḥ kāṅkṣā vitarka ūha karma bhedeṣu kīrttyate
translated: Tarka is declared to be doubt and reasoning in the matter of the difference of actions.

original: śloko yaśasi padye ca lokastu bhuvane jane //
analyzed: ślokaḥ yaśasi padye ca lokaḥ tu bhuvane jane
translated: A verse is a metrical composition, and a śloka is a metrical composition of four lines. Loka is the world, and loka is people.

original: stoko'lpe cātake tokamaptyaputrayorapi // //🔽kokaścakre vṛke jyeṣṭhayā kharjjūrīdumabhekayoḥ //
analyzed: stoka ulpe cātake toka maptya putrayoḥ api  / kokaḥ cakre vṛke jyeṣṭhayā kharjjūrī duma bhekayoḥ
translated: Stoka is a little, and a stoka is a small bird. Toke is a child, and toke is a son.🔽A kokila is a cuckoo, and a kokila is a wolf. Jyeshthya is a female animal, and jyeshthya is a female bird. Kharjūra is a date palm, and a kharjūra is a frog.

analyzed: rokaḥ dīptau bile na eka ākrayaṇa bhedayoḥ
translated: Roka is a hole, and roka is a kind of bird. Roka is a kind of bird, and roka is a kind of bird.

analyzed: vekaḥ vidagdhe chekaḥ ca viśvasta mṛga pakṣiṇoḥ
translated: Vika is a clever person, and a vika is a bird. Vika is a clever person, and a vika is a bird.

original: reko vireke śaṅkāyā rekaḥ syādavame'pi ca // //
analyzed: rekaḥ vireke śaṅkāyāḥ rekaḥ syāt avame api ca
translated: Reka is a kind of bird, and reka is a kind of bird. Reka is a kind of bird, and reka is a kind of bird.

original: kākaḥ syādvāyase vṛkṣaprabhede pīṭhasapiṇi //🔽śirobakṣāline mānaviśeṣadīpabhedayoḥ // //🔽kākā syāt kākanāsāyā kākolīkākajaṅghayoḥ //

translated: A kāka is a crow, and a kāka is a kind of tree. A kāka is a crow, and a kāka is a kind of tree.🔽A kāka is a kind of tree, and a kāka is a kind of tree. A kāka is a kind of tree, and a kāka is a kind of tree.🔽A kāka is a kind of tree, and a kāka is a kind of tree. A kāka is a kind of tree, and a kāka is a kind of tree.

original: rakte kāyā malapvāñca kākamācyāñca kīttitā // //🔽kāka strīratabandhe syāt kākānāmapi sahatau //🔽pākaḥ śiśau jarāniṣṭhāpacanakledaneṣu ca // //🔽śāko dvīpāntare śaktau nṛpadrumaviśeṣayoḥ //

translated: A kāka is a kind of tree, and a kāka is a kind of tree. A kāka is a kind of tree, and a kāka is a kind of tree.🔽A kāka is a kind of tree, and a kāka is a kind of tree. A kāka is a kind of tree, and a kāka is a kind of tree.🔽A kāka is a kind of tree, and a kāka is a kind of tree. A kāka is a kind of tree, and a kāka is a kind of tree.

analyzed: śāka haritake ca api nākaḥ svarga antarikṣayoḥ  /
translated: A kāka is a kind of tree, and a kāka is a kind of tree. A kāka is a kind of tree, and a kāka is a kind of tree.🔽A kāka is a kind of tree,

analyzed: mūka upya vāc matau dīne śūkaḥ nu krośa śṛṅgayoḥ
translated: Mūka is used in the sense of dumb, in the case of a bird, and in the case of a frog.

original: bhūkaśchidre ca kāle ca bheko maṇḍūkameghayoḥ // //
analyzed: bhūkaḥ chidre ca kāle ca bhekaḥ maṇḍūka meghayoḥ
translated: Bhūka is used in the sense of a hole, in the case of time, and in the case of a frog.

analyzed: kevala śreṣṭhaḥ itarasmin ca vācya vat
translated: Eka is used in the sense of only, excellent, and in the case of the other, like the object.

analyzed: śauka śuka samūhe ca strīṇām ca karaṇa antare
translated: Śauka is used in the sense of a flock of parrots, and in the case of women, in another case.

analyzed: aṅkaḥ sthāna intike mantau rūpaka utsaṅga lakṣmasu
translated: Aṅka is used in the sense of a place, near, a vow, a figure, a lap, and in the characteristics.

original: nāṭikādiparicchede citrayuddhe ca bhūṣaṇe // //🔽kaṅkaśchadmadvije khyāto lohapṛṣṭhakṛtāntayoḥ //
analyzed: nāṭikā ādi paricchede citra yuddhe ca bhūṣaṇe  kaṅkaḥ chadma dvije khyātaḥ loha pṛṣṭha kṛtāntayoḥ
translated: In the section of Nāṭikā etc., in a wonderful battle, and in an ornament.🔽Kaṅka is known in the sense of a deceitful twice-born, and in the case of iron and the end.

original: vaṅkaḥ paryyāṇabhāge syānnadīpātre ca bhaṅgure // //🔽ṭaṅkaḥ kapitthabhede syānmānāntarakhanitrayoḥ //🔽kope'sikośe jaṅghāyā ṭaṅkaṇe grāvadāraṇe // //
analyzed: vaṅkaḥ paryyāṇa bhāge syāt nadī pātre ca bhaṅgure  ṭaṅkaḥ kapittha bhede syāt māna antara khanitrayoḥ  kopesikośe jaṅghāyāḥ ṭaṅkaṇe grāvadāraṇe
translated: Vaṅka is used in the sense of a saddle part, and in the case of a river vessel and a fragile one.🔽Ṭaṅka is used in the sense of a variety of wood-apple, and in the case of a measuring instrument and a spade.🔽In anger, in the case of a sword sheath, in the case of a leg, in the case of sulphate of copper, and in the case of a stone-cutter.

analyzed: raṅkaḥ tu kṛpaṇe malle paṅkaḥ darddama pāpayoḥ
translated: Raṅka is used in the sense of miserly, in the case of a wrestler, and in the case of mud and sin.

analyzed: nyaṅkuḥ mṛge ṛṣau nākuḥ vāmalūre girau munau
translated: Nyaṅku is used in the sense of a deer, in the case of a sage, and in the case of a kind of sugar-cane, in the case of a mountain, and in the case of a sage.

analyzed: śaṅkuḥ kīle śivesre ca
translated: Śaṅku is used in the sense of a peg, in the case of Śiva, and in the case of a weapon, and in the case of a friend, and in the case of the two kinds of Adya.

analyzed: kalkaḥ pāpa āśaye pāpe dambhe viṣ kiṭṭayoḥ api
translated: Kalka is used in the sense of a sinful intention, in the case of sin, and in the case of hypocrisy, and in the case of feces and dross.

analyzed: khaṇḍe śalka śakalavalkayoḥ
translated: Valka means a piece of bark, and shulka means a scale or a piece of bark.

analyzed: śulka ghaṭṭa ādi deye syāt jāmātuḥ bandhake pi ca
translated: Shulka also means a tax or toll, and is used in the sense of a relative's bond.

analyzed: niṣkam aṣṭa adhika svarṇa śate dīnāra karpayoḥ
translated: Nishka means 180 grains of gold, and is used for a dinara and a karpa.

original: vakṣo'laṅkaraṇe hemapātre hemapale'pi ca // //🔽muṣko'ṇḍakośe saṅghāte muṣko mokṣe ca pādaye //
analyzed: vakṣaḥ ulaṅkaraṇe hema pātre hema palepi ca  muṣka uṇḍa kośe saṅghāte muṣkaḥ mokṣe ca
translated: Vaksha means an ornament for the chest, a golden vessel, and a pala of gold.🔽Mushka means the scrotum, a collection, and is used in the sense of a foot in the act of liberation.

original: kiṣkurvitastau haste ca prakoṣṭhe kutsite'pi ca // //
analyzed: kiṣkuḥ vitastau haste ca prakoṣṭhe kutsite pi ca
translated: Kishku means a cubit, a span, and is used in the sense of a forearm and a contemptible person.

original: trikākūpasya nemau syāt trika pṛṣṭhādhare traye //
analyzed: trikākūpasya nemau syāt trika pṛṣṭha adhare traye
translated: Nemis are the three circular lines on the forehead, and trika means the three lower parts of the back.

analyzed: laṅkā rakṣaḥpurī śākhā śākinī kulaṭāsu ca
translated: Lanka means the city of the Rakshasas, a branch, a female spirit, and a prostitute.

original: śaṅkā trāse vitarke ca rākā tu saridantare //
analyzed: śaṅkā trāse vitarke ca rākā tu sarit antare
translated: Shankha means fear, doubt, and Raksha is used for a river and its bank.

analyzed: kacchū navara ja kanyā pūrṇa indu pūrṇimāsu ca
translated: Kachchu means an inferior washerman's daughter, a full moon, and the full moon night.

analyzed: katrikam  kanaka campake svarṇe kiśuke nāgakeśare
translated: Katrika means a kind of bird.🔽Kanaka means gold, and is used for a Champaka flower and a Kshivaka flower.

original: dhuttūre kāñcanāre ca kālīye'pi kkacinmatam // //🔽karakastu karaṅke syāddāḍime ca kamaṇḍalau //
analyzed: dhuttūre kāñcanāre ca kālīye api kkacid matam  karakaḥ tu karaṅke syāt dāḍime ca kamaṇḍalau
translated: Dhuttura and Kanchara are used for Kaliya in some places.🔽Karaka means a pot, a pomegranate, and a water pot.

original: pakṣibhede kare cāpi karakā ca ghanopale // //
analyzed: pakṣibhede kare ca api karakā ca ghanopale
translated: Karaka is also used for a kind of bird and a hand, and Karaka is used for a snow mountain.

analyzed: narakaḥ niraye daitye sarakaḥ sīdhu bhājane
translated: Naraka, in hell, Daitya, in Saraka, a vessel for Sidhu (wine),

analyzed: acchinna adhvaga paṅkau ca sīdhu pāne ca sīdhuni
translated: In the uninterrupted path of travelers and in the drinking of Sidhu, in Sidhu,

original: khanakaścittatattvajñe sandhicaure ca mūṣike //🔽janakaḥ pitṛrājarṣyoryutaka saśaye yuge // //
analyzed: khanakaḥ citta tattva jñe sandhi caure ca mūṣike  janakaḥ pitṛ rāja ṛṣyoḥ yutaka saśaye yuge  /
translated: Khanaka, one who knows the truth of the mind, in a thief who breaks into houses, and in a mouse,🔽Janaka, in the father and in the royal sages, Yutaka, in doubt, in a pair,

analyzed: yautake calana agre ca strī vastra añcala yuktayoḥ
translated: In Yautaka, in moving forward, in the border of a woman's garment,

original: kṛṣakaḥ karṣake phāle rajako dhāvake śuke // //
analyzed: kṛṣakaḥ karṣake phāle rajakaḥ dhāvake śuke  /
translated: Krishaka, in a farmer, in a plow, Rajaka, in a washerman, in a parrot,

analyzed: madhukaḥ vandi bhede syāt jyeṣṭhayā addhe vihaga antare
translated: Madhuka, in a kind of praise, in the next-to-highest, in a bird,

analyzed: madhuka madhuparṇyā syāt anukaḥ nipuṇa alpayoḥ
translated: Madhuka, in Madhuparni, Anuka, in a skillful one, in a small one,

original: vasukaḥ śivamallyā syādarkkaparṇe ca romake //🔽śiśukaḥ śiśumāre syādbālakolūpinorapi // //
analyzed: vasukaḥ śivamallyā syāt arkkaparṇe ca romake  śiśukaḥ śiśumāre syāt bālaka ulūpinoḥ api
translated: Vasuka, in Shiva, in Malli, in Arka-parni, in Romika,🔽Shishuka, in Shishu-mara, in a child, in a mongoose,
Kramuka, in Pattika, in Lodhra, in Bhadra, in Mustaka, in a bunch of plantains,

analyzed: phale kārpāsikāyāḥ ca kramukaḥ brahmadāruṇi
translated: In the fruit of Karpasika, Kramuka, in Brahmadaru,

analyzed: bahukaḥ karkkaṭa irkke ca dātyūhe jalakhātake
translated: Bahuka, in Karkata, in Arka, in a kind of partridge, in a water tank,

analyzed: dhanikaḥ sādhu dhanyāka dhaveṣu dhanikā striyām
translated: Dhanika, in a good one, in Dhannya, in a cloth, Dhanika, in a woman,
Priyaka, in yellow rice, in a kind of tree, in a spotted deer, in a bear,

original: kaṅkume ca priyaṅgau ca pṛthukaścipiṭe śiśau // //
analyzed: kaṅkume ca priyaṅgau ca pṛthukaḥ cipiṭe śiśau
translated: Kanka and Priyangu are used for Pithuka and Chipita in a child.

analyzed: yamaka yama je śabda alaṅkāre ca
translated: Yamaka is used for twins and in the figure of speech Yamaka.

original: maśakaḥ kathyate kṣudrarogajantuviśeṣayoḥ // //🔽kulakantu paṭole syācchlokasambandhagucchake //🔽kulakaḥ syāt kulaśreṣṭhe valmīke kākatinduke // //
analyzed: maśakaḥ kathyate kṣudra roga jantu viśeṣayoḥ            kulakaḥ syāt kulaśreṣṭhe valmīke kākatinduke  /
translated: Mashaka is used for a small insect and a particular small disease.🔽Kulanta is used for Patola, a group of verses, and a bunch.🔽Kulanta is used for the best of the family, an ant-hill, and a kind of tree.

original: tilaka citrake prāhurlalāme tilakālake //🔽rāgavidrumabhedepu lomni sauvarcale'pi ca // //
analyzed: tilaka citrake prāhuḥ lalāme tilakālake  rāga vidruma bhedeṣu lomni sauvarcale pi ca
translated: Tilaka is used for a picture, a mark on the forehead, and a sesame seed.🔽Ragavindruma is used for a kind of coral and for hair.

original: kuliko nāgabhede syād drubhede kulasattame //🔽kuśikaḥ syānmunau tailaśeṣe sarjjākṣavṛkṣayoḥ // //
analyzed: kulikaḥ nāga bhede syāt dru bhede kula sattame  kuśikaḥ syāt munau taila śeṣe sarjja akṣa vṛkṣayoḥ
translated: Kulinka is used for a kind of serpent and for the best of trees.🔽Kushtaka is used for a sage, for the residue of oil, and for two kinds of trees.

original: caṣakantu surāpātre madhumasyaprabhedayoḥ //🔽caṭakaḥ kalaviṅke syāccaṭakā tatstryapatyayoḥ // //
analyzed: caṣakam tu surā pātre madhu masya prabhedayoḥ  caṭakaḥ kalaviṅke syāt caṭakā tad strī apatyayoḥ
translated: Chashtaka is used for a cup for drinking wine and for two kinds of honey.🔽Chataka is used for a sparrow and for the female of the same and for their young.

analyzed: kaṭaka valaye sānau rājadhānī nitambayoḥ
translated: Kataka is used for an ornament, a hill, a capital city, and the buttocks.

original: sāmudralavaṇe dantamaṇḍale dantināmapi // //🔽kaṭukā kaṭurohiṇyā vyoṣe'pi kaṭuka smṛtam //
analyzed: sāmudralavaṇe dantamaṇḍale dantinām api
translated: Samudra Lavana is used for salt and for the tusks of elephants.🔽Katruka is used for Katu Rohini and for a kind of pungent herb.

analyzed: culukaḥ prasutau bhāṇḍa bhede culuka vat mataḥ
translated: Chulukaka is used for a vessel for drinking water and for a kind of vessel.
Pulka is used in the sense of an insect, a cluster of sun-crystals, and a fault.

original: gajānnapiṇḍe rāmāñce haritāle śilāntare // //🔽rucaka maṅgaladravye grīvābharaṇadantayoḥ //
analyzed: gaja anna piṇḍe rāmāñce haritāle śilā antare  rucaka maṅgala dravye grīvā ābharaṇa dantayoḥ
translated: In the case of an elephant's food, a ball, Rāma, yellow orpiment, and a stone.🔽Rucaka is used for auspicious articles, a necklace, and teeth.

analyzed: utkaṭe bījapūre ca sauvarcala viḍaṅgayoḥ  /
translated: Utkaṭa is used for a kind of bean, a kind of cucumber, and for Sauvarchala and Viḍaṅga.

analyzed: rocanāyām ca rucakam aśva ābharaṇa mālyayoḥ
translated: Rucaka is used for a kind of ointment, a horse's ornament, and a garland.🔽Kṣuraka is used for a kind of cucumber, a plant with red flowers, and a tree.

analyzed: kāmukaḥ kanama aśoka pādape ca atimuktake
translated: Kāmuka is used for a kind of cucumber, a plant with red flowers, and a tree.

original: pātukaḥ pātayālau syāt prapātajalahastinoḥ // //🔽ānakaḥ paṭahe bheryyā mṛdaṅge svanadambude //
analyzed: pātukaḥ pātayālau syāt prapāta jalahastinoḥ  / ānakaḥ paṭahe bheryāḥ mṛdaṅge svanat ambude
translated: Pātuka is used for a kind of cucumber, a plant with red flowers, and a tree.🔽Ānaka is used for a kind of drum, a kettle-drum, and a tabor.

analyzed: āḍhaka māna bhede syāt tuvaryyām āḍhakī matā
translated: Āḍhaka is used for a measure, and Āḍhakī is considered to be a kind of bean.

original: kārakaḥ karttari proktaḥ karmmādāvapi kārakam //🔽cārakaḥ pālake'śvādeḥ syāt sañcārakabandhayoḥ // //🔽tārakaḥ karṇadhāre syāddaitye ca dṛśi tārakam //
analyzed: kārakaḥ karttari proktaḥ karmma ādau api kārakam  cārakaḥ pālaka īśva ādeḥ syāt sañcāraka bandhayoḥ   tārakaḥ karṇadhāre syāt daitye ca dṛśi tārakam
translated: Kāraka is used for an agent, and kāraka is also used for an object, etc.🔽Cāruka is used for a keeper of horses, etc., and for a kind of cucumber, and for a band.🔽Tāruka is used for an earring, a demon, and for the eye.

analyzed: kanīnikāyāḥ nakṣatre tāraka tāraka iti ca
translated: Tāruka is used for the pupil of the eye, and for a star.

analyzed: vāra kośva gatau aśva viśeṣe ca niṣedhake
translated: Vāraka is used for a horse, a particular horse, and for a prohibition.

analyzed: jāhakaḥ ghoṅkha mārjjāra khaṭvā kāruṇḍikāsu ca
translated: Jahaka is used for a cat, a crow, a bed, a pot, and a kind of musical instrument.

analyzed: pāvaka ugnau sadācāre vahnimanthe ca citrake
translated: Pavaka is used for fire, good conduct, a kind of fire-drill, and a kind of picture.

analyzed: bhallātake viḍaṅge ca sāyakaḥ śara khaṅgayoḥ
translated: Bhallataka is used for a kind of myrobalan, and Vidanga is used for a kind of plant. Sayaka is used for an arrow and a sword.

analyzed: nāyakaḥ netari śreṣṭhe hāra madhya maṇau api
translated: Nayaka is used for a leader, an excellent one, and a necklace. It is also used for a middle gem.

analyzed: prāṇakaḥ sattva jātīye jīvaka druma velayoḥ  /
translated: Pranaka is used for a living being, a kind of tree, and a kind of creeper.
Jalak is used for a kind of grain, and Jalini is used for a kind of fruit.

original: ānāye dambhabhede ca vastrabhede ca jālikā // //🔽bālako'gre śiśau keśe vājivāraṇabāladhau //
analyzed: ānāye dambha bhede ca vastra bhede ca jālikā  bālaka ugre śiśau keśe vāji vāraṇa bāladhau
translated: Anaya is used for deceit, for a kind of cloth, and for a net.🔽Balaka is used for a young one, a child, hair, a horse, an elephant, and a young elephant.

analyzed: aṅgulīyaka hīvera pārihāryeṣu bālakam
translated: Balaka is used for a ring, a kind of plant, and a kind of ornament.

analyzed: vārddhaka vṛddha saṅghāte vṛddha tve vṛddha karmmāṇi
translated: Vardhaka is used for an old man, a collection of old people, old age, and old deeds.

analyzed: yājakaḥ yājini khyātaḥ yājakaḥ rāja kuñjare
translated: Yajaka is known as a priest, a king, and an elephant.

analyzed: grāhakaḥ ghāta vihage vyālānām ca grahītari
translated: Grahaka is used for a killer of birds, and a catcher of wild animals.

analyzed: dārakaḥ bhedakepatye rātraka pañcarāke
translated: Daraka is used for a child, and Rathaka is used for a five-day period.

analyzed: yena veśyā gṛhe nītaḥ vatsaraḥ tatra rātrakaḥ
translated: Rathaka is used for a year spent in a prostitute's house.

analyzed: lāsaka ulasake lāsya kāriṇī api mayūrake
translated: Lasaka is used for a lazy person, a dancer, and a peacock.

analyzed: śārkakaḥ śarkarā piṇḍe dugdha phene ca śārkakaḥ
translated: Sharkaka is used for a lump of sugar and for foam in milk.

original: hārakaḥ kitave caure gadyavijñānabhedayoḥ //🔽sthāsakākhyā ca cārccikye jalāderapi budbude // //
analyzed: hārakaḥ kitave caure gadya vijñāna bhedayoḥ  sthāsaka ākhyā ca cārccikye jala ādeḥ api budbude
translated: Haraka is used for a gambler, a thief, and for prose and for the two kinds of knowledge.🔽Sthāsakā is used for a small coin, for a lamp, and also for a bubble of water and so on.

analyzed: drāvakaḥ tu śilā bhede vidagdhe moṣake api ca
translated: Drāvaka is used for the breaking of a stone, for a clever person, and also for a thief.

original: bhrāmako jambuke dhūrte sūryāvartāśmabhedayoḥ // //🔽piṇyākaḥ sihake hiṅgau tilacūrṇe'pi kuṅkume //
analyzed: piṇyākaḥ sihake hiṅgau tila cūrṇe api kuṅkume
translated: Bhramāka is used for a jackal, for a cunning person, and for the two kinds of stone that resemble the sun's disc.🔽Piṇyāka is used for a kind of cake, for a kind of ginger, and also for sesame powder and saffron.

analyzed: pinākaḥ hara kodaṇḍe pāśu varṣa triśūlayoḥ   kāvṛkaḥ kṛkavākau syā pītamustaka kokayoḥ
translated: Pināka is used for Śiva's bow, for a kind of rain, and for a trident.🔽Kāvṛka is used for a cock, for a kind of yellow nutgrass, and for a cuckoo.

analyzed: kṣārakaḥ pakṣi matsya ādi piṭake jālake api ca
translated: Kṣārakas is used for a cage for birds and fish, and also for a net.

analyzed: pāṭakaḥ syāt mahākiṣkau kaṭaka antara vādyayoḥ
translated: Pāṭaka is used for a large kite, and for the two kinds of musical instruments.

analyzed: akṣa ādi cālane mūla dravya upacaya vedhasoḥ
translated: Akṣādi-cālane is used for the movement of dice and so on, for the accumulation of basic substances, and for piercing.

analyzed: varākaḥ saṅgare śocye parākaḥ vrata khaṅgayoḥ
translated: Varāka is used for a battle, for something pitiable, and for a vow and a sword.

analyzed: pulākaḥ tuccha dhānye syāt saṅkṣepe bhakta sikthake  /
translated: Pulāka is used for worthless grain, for brevity, and for the dregs of boiled rice.

original: vipākaḥ kīrttyate svādau pariṇāme ca durgatau //
analyzed: vipākaḥ kīrttyate svādau pariṇāme ca durgatau
translated: Vipāka is used for sweetness and for the bad state of ripening.

analyzed: vipākaḥ pacane svede api asat karmma phale api ca
translated: Vipāka is used in the sense of cooking, sweating, and also in the sense of the result of bad actions.

analyzed: lampākaḥ lampaṭe deśe śimphākaḥ śapha mūrkhayoḥ
translated: Lampāka is used in the sense of a foolish country, Śimphāka is used in the sense of a hoof and a fool.

analyzed: sampākaḥ trkike dhṛṣṭe sampākaḥ catur aṅgule
translated: Sampāka is used in the sense of a group of three, a bold person, and a four-finger length.🔽Mocaka is used in the sense of a plantain, a kind of pulse, a kind of cucumber, and a kind of jasmine.

original: pecako gajalāṅgūlamūlaparyyantaghūkayoḥ // //🔽mecako barhicandre syānmecakaḥ śyāmale'pi ca //
analyzed: pecakaḥ gaja lāṅgūla mūla paryyanta ghūkayoḥ   / mecakaḥ barhi candre syāt mecakaḥ śyāmale pi ca
translated: Pepaka is used in the sense of the root of an elephant's tail, and a kind of owl.🔽Mecaka is used in the sense of a peacock and the moon, and mecaka is used in the sense of a dark color.

analyzed: timire kṛṣṇa varṇe tu mecaka vācya vat bhavet
translated: Timira is used in the sense of a dark color, and mecaka is used in the sense of a dark color.

original: sūcakaḥ sīvanadravye bodhake vṛṣadaśake //🔽piśune śuni kāke ca kecakaḥ sektṛmeghayoḥ // //
analyzed: sūcakaḥ sīvana dravye bodhake vṛṣa daśake  piśune śuni kāke ca kecakaḥ sektṛ meghayoḥ
translated: Sūcaka is used in the sense of a sewing instrument, and in the sense of a teacher, and a group of ten bulls.🔽Kecaka is used in the sense of a leaker, a dog, a crow, and a cloud.

original: locako māsapiṇḍesyādakṣṇi tāre ca kaṅgule //🔽lalāṭābharaṇe strīṇā kadalīnīlavastrayoḥ // //
analyzed: locakaḥ tāre ca kaṅgule  lalāṭa ābharaṇe strīṇā kadalī nīla vastrayoḥ
translated: Locaka is used in the sense of a lump of dough, an eye, a star, and a kind of grass.🔽Kadalinī is used in the sense of an ornament on the forehead of women, and in the sense of a plantain and a blue garment.

analyzed: nirbuddhau karṇapūre ca maurvyāḥ bhū ślatha carmmaṇi
translated: Nirbuddha is used in the sense of an earring, and in the sense of loose skin on the forehead due to old age.

original: modako harṣake jñeyaḥ khādyabhede ca modakam // //🔽kholakaḥ pākavalmīkapūgakoṣaśirastrake //
analyzed: modakaḥ harṣake jñeyaḥ khādya bhede ca modakam  kholakaḥ pāka valmīka pūga koṣa śirastrake
translated: Modaka is known to be used in the sense of joy, and in the sense of a kind of sweet.🔽Khālaka is used in the sense of a cooked anthill, a betel nut, a sheath, and a turban.

analyzed: golakaḥ vidhavā putre jārāt ca maṇike guḍe
translated: Golaka is used in the sense of the son of a widow, and in the sense of a paramour, a gem, and molasses.

original: kūpako guṇavṛkṣe syāttailapātre kukundare //🔽udapāne citāyāñca kūpikā'mbhogatopale // //
analyzed: kūpakaḥ guṇa vṛkṣe syāt taila pātre kukundare  udapāne citāyām ca kūpikā ambhaḥ gata upale
translated: Kupa is used for a well, a tree with good qualities, an oil vessel, and a cucumber.🔽Udapana is used for a water tank, a funeral pyre, a well, and a stone obtained from water.

original: kūlakaḥ kṛmiśaile ca pratīrastūpayorapi //🔽rūpaka nāṭake dhūrte kāvyālaṅkaraṇe viduḥ // //
analyzed: kūlakaḥ kṛmiśaile ca pratīra stūpayoḥ api  rūpaka nāṭake dhūrte kāvya alaṅkaraṇe viduḥ
translated: Kulaka is used for an ant-hill, a mountain of worms, and for the banks of a river and a hill.🔽Rupaka is known as a drama, a deceitful person, and an ornament of poetry.

analyzed: cṛtakaḥ kūpake pyāmre sūtaka rasa janmanoḥ
translated: Chutaka is used for a well, a mango tree, and for the impurity arising from childbirth and the birth of a child.

original: lūnakaḥ syāt paśau bhinne śūcakaḥ prāvaṭe rase // //🔽kīcako daityabhede syācchuṣkavaśe drumāntare //
analyzed: lūnakaḥ syāt paśau bhinne śūcakaḥ prāvaṭe rase  / kīcakaḥ daityabhede syāt śuṣkavaśe druma antare
translated: Lunkaka is used for a broken animal, and shuchaka is used for a water pot and a liquid.🔽Kichaka is used for a type of demon, and for a dry bamboo, and for another kind of tree.

original: kīṭakaḥ kṛmibhede syānniṣṭhure kīṭako'nyavat // //🔽jīvakaḥ pītaśāle syāt kṣapaṇe vṛddhajīvini //
analyzed: kīṭakaḥ kṛmi bhede syāt niṣṭhure kīṭakonya vat      syāt
translated: Kitika is used for a type of worm, and kitika is used for a harsh sound like any other.🔽Jivaka is used for yellow rice, for a long-lived old person, and for a leech.

analyzed: sevini prāṇakepyā ahituṇḍike pādapa antare
translated: It is also used for a living being, a snake charmer, and for another kind of tree.

original: ājīve jīvikāmāhurjīvantyāmapi kutracit //🔽dīpaka vāgalaṅkāre dīpako dīptikārake // //
analyzed: ājīve jīvikām āhuḥ jīvantyām api kutracid  dīpaka vāc alaṅkāre dīpakaḥ dīpti kārake  /
translated: In some places, it is said that jivaka is used for livelihood and for a living person.🔽Dipika is used for an ornament of speech, and for one who causes illumination.
Chiraka is considered as a kind of writing, and chirika is used for a hundred.

analyzed: sevakaḥ tu praseve syāt anujīvini ca anya vat
translated: Sevaka is used for a servant, and for one who depends on another.

analyzed: aśokaḥ vañjule māne druma niḥśokayoḥ mataḥ
translated: Ashoka is used for a kind of tree, for a bamboo, for respect, and for a tree without sorrow.

analyzed: kaṭurohiṇyām aśoka pādape smṛtam
translated: Aśoka is known for the bitter Rohini plant and the Aśoka tree.

analyzed: ālokaḥ darśane dyote ālokaḥ vandi bhāṣaṇe
translated: Āloka is used for seeing, illuminating, and praising.

analyzed: peṭaka pustaka ādīnā pañjūṣāṇā kadambake
translated: Peṭaka is used for books and other things, and pañjūṣā for a collection of them.

analyzed: herakaḥ buddha bhede syāt mahākāla gaṇe pi ca
translated: Heraka is used for a different Buddha and also for the Mahākāla Gaṇa.

analyzed: dhenuka karaṇe strīṇām dhenūnām api sahatau
translated: Dhenuka is used for the act of women and also for the combination of cows.

original: vivekaḥ syājjaladroṇyā vicāre'pi rahasyapi //🔽gairika kanake dhātau prasekaḥ secane cyutauḥ // //
analyzed: vivekaḥ syāt jala droṇyāḥ vicāre api rahasi api  gairika kanake dhātau prasekaḥ secane cyutauḥ
translated: Viveka is used for a water pot and also for consideration and secrecy.🔽Gairika is used for red chalk and gold, and prasaṅka for sprinkling and falling.

original: vaijike śigrutaile ca hetau sadyo'ṅkure'pi ca /🔽koraka kuḍmale vidyāt kakkolakamṛṇālayoḥ // //
analyzed: vaijike śigru taile ca hetau sadyas uṅkure pi ca  koraka kuḍmale vidyāt kakkolaka mṛṇālayoḥ
translated: Vaijika is used for mustard oil and also for cause and sudden sprout.🔽Koraka should be known for buds and also for kakkola and lotus stalks.

analyzed: kautukam ca abhilāṣe syāt utsave narmma harpayoḥ
translated: Kautuka is used for desire, festival, and for the king's sport.

analyzed: paramparā samāyāta maṅgale ca kutūhale
translated: Paramparyāgata is used for the auspicious and the curious.

original: vivare sūtragītādibhogakāleṣu ca smṛtam //🔽kauśiko nakule vyālagrāhe gugguluśakrayoḥ // //🔽viśvāmitre ca kośāgryolūkayorapi kauśikaḥ //
analyzed: vivare sūtra gīta ādi bhoga kāleṣu ca smṛtam  kauśikaḥ nakule vyāla grāhe guggulu śakrayoḥ    viśvāmitre ca kośāgrya ulūkayoḥ api kauśikaḥ
translated: Vivara is remembered for the time of enjoying sūtras, songs, etc.🔽Kauśika is used for Nakula, catching snakes, and for Guṅgula and Śakra.🔽Kauśika is also used for Viśvāmitra, the chief of the treasury, and for owls.

analyzed: kauśikī caṇḍikāyām ca nadī bhede ca kauśikī
translated: Kauśikī is used for Caṇḍikā and also for a type of river.

analyzed: pratīkaḥ uvayave proktaḥ pratikūla vilomayoḥ  bhūtīkam api bhūnimba dīpya karpūra kattṛṇe
translated: Pratik is said to be a part, and pratikula and viloma mean adverse and contrary respectively.🔽Bhūtīka also means bhūnimba, dīpya, karpūra, and kaṭṭiṇa.

original: abhīkaḥ kāmuke krūre kavau ca bhayavarjite //
analyzed: abhīkaḥ kāmuke krūre kavau ca bhaya varjite
translated: Abhika means one who is in love, cruel, and fearless in poetry.

analyzed: valmīkaḥ vāmalūre syāt muni roga viśeṣayoḥ
translated: Valmīka means a kind of ant-hill and a particular disease of horses.

original: anīkantu priye prokta vyalīko nāgare smṛtaḥ //
analyzed: anīkam tu vyalīkaḥ nāgare smṛtaḥ
translated: Anīka means a beloved one, and vyālīka is known to be a nāgara (a kind of Sanskrit poetry).

analyzed: vyalīkam apriya akārye vailakṣyeṣu api pīḍane
translated: Vyālīka also means unpleasant action and affliction in shameful acts.

original: nālīka śarakhaṇḍe'bje nālīkaḥ śaraśalyayoḥ //🔽alīkamapriye proktamalīkamanṛte'pi ca // //
analyzed: nālīka śara khaṇḍa ibje nālīkaḥ śara śalyayoḥ  alīkam apriye proktam alīkam anṛte api ca
translated: Nālīka means a piece of arrow, a lotus, and a kind of arrow.🔽Alīka means unpleasant and false.

analyzed: kule śīle ipi anūkaḥ gata janmani
translated: Anūka means a family and good character, and anūka also means a past birth.

original: ulūkaḥ kuravinde syāt pecake jambhabhedini // //🔽śambūko gajakumbhānte daityabhede ca ghoṅgake //🔽bandhūko bandhujīve syād bandhūkaḥ pītaśālake // //
analyzed: ulūkaḥ kuravinde syāt pecake jambha bhedini  śambūkaḥ gaja kumbha ante daityabhede ca ghoṅgake  bandhūkaḥ bandhujīve syāt bandhūkaḥ pītaśālake
translated: Ulūka means a kind of bird and a kind of weapon.🔽Śambūka means the forehead of an elephant and a kind of demon.🔽Bandhūka means a kind of flower and a yellow śāla tree.

original: maṇḍūka bandhubhede'pi dardure śoṇake biduḥ //🔽maṇḍūkaparṇyā maṇḍūkī varṇakaścāraṇe smṛtaḥ // //
analyzed: maṇḍūka bandhubhede pi dardure śoṇake biduḥ  maṇḍūkaparṇyāḥ maṇḍūkī varṇakaḥ cāraṇe smṛtaḥ
translated: Mandūka means a frog and a kind of relative.🔽Mandūkaparṇī is also called mandūki, and varṇaka is known to be a kind of pigment.

analyzed: vilepane candane ca varṇaka syāt atha arbhakaḥ
translated: Varṇaka also means sandal paste and a child.

original: ḍimbhe mūrkhe kṛśe bhrūṇe vartako'śvakhure khage // //
analyzed: ḍimbhe mūrkhe kṛśe bhrūṇe varta kośu akhure khage  /
translated: Dimbha is used for a fool, a weak fetus, a worm, a horse's hoof, and a bird.

analyzed: ratna kaṅkaṇe
translated: Pushpaka is used for a flower, a pleasure, an eye disease, a jewel, and a bracelet.

original: kuberasya vimāne ca kāśīśe ca rasāṅjane // //🔽lohe kāsye mṛdaṅgāraśakaṭayāmapi puṣpakam //
analyzed: kuberasya vimāne ca kāsīse ca rasāṅjane  lohe kāsye mṛd aṅgāra śakaṭayām api puṣpakam
translated: The Vimāna of Kubera, the lord of Kāśī, and the collyrium of mercury.🔽Pushpaka is used for iron, brass, charcoal, a cart, and a measure.

analyzed: pūrṇakaḥ svarṇacūḍe syāt nāsācchinnyāḥ tu pūrṇikā
translated: Pūrṇaka is used for a golden crest, and Pūrṇikā for a cut nose.

analyzed: darśakaḥ syāt pratīhāre darśayitṛ pravīṇayoḥ
translated: Darśaka is used for a doorkeeper, and Darśayitr for an expert in showing.
Padmaka is used for a lotus, a lotus tree, a drop, and a net.

analyzed: dīpyakaḥ ca ajamode syāt yavānī barhicūḍayoḥ
translated: Dīpyaka is used for ajamoda, yavānī, and a peacock's crest.

analyzed: sasyakaḥ syāt maṇau khaḍge nārikelasya ca antare
translated: Sasyaka is used for a gem, a sword, and a coconut.

analyzed: raktakaḥ mlāna bandhūka rakta vastra anurāgiṣu
translated: Raktaka is used for a faded relative, red cloth, and one who is fond of red.

original: citrakaḥ syāttaruvyāghrabhedayorbheṣajāntare // //🔽vṛścikastu druṇe rāśau śūkakīṭe tathauṣadhe //🔽aśuka sūkṣmavastre syādvastramātrottarīyayoḥ // //
analyzed: citrakaḥ syāt taru vyāghrabhedayoḥ bheṣaja antare  / vṛścikaḥ tu druṇe rāśau śūka kīṭe tathā auṣadhe  sūkṣma vastre syāt vastra mātra uttarīyayoḥ
translated: Citraka is used for a kind of tiger, a kind of medicine, and a kind of herb.🔽Vṛścika is used for the sign Scorpio, a stinging insect, and a medicinal plant.🔽Aśuka is used for a fine cloth, and a cloth is used for a mere upper garment.

analyzed: antika nikaṭe cullyām antikā śītala auṣadhe
translated: Antaka is used for near, for a stove, and for a cooling medicine.

original: tathā jyeṣṭhabhaginyāñca nāṭayoktau kīrttyate'ntikā // //🔽svastiko maṅgaladravye catuṣkagṛhabhedayoḥ //
analyzed: tathā jyeṣṭha bhaginyām ca nāṭaya uktau  svastikaḥ maṅgala dravye catuṣka gṛha bhedayoḥ
translated: Similarly, in the case of the elder sister, it is said to be Nāṭa and Uktā in the vicinity.🔽Svastika is used for auspicious substances, for the four types of houses,

analyzed: piṣṭakasya vikāre ca svastikaḥ rajata alike
translated: and for the modification of flour, and Svastika is used for silver ornaments.

original: kañcuko vāravāṇe syānnirmmoke kavace'pi //🔽varddhāpakagṛhītāṅgasthitavastre ca colake // //🔽auṣadhau kañcukī cātha vañcakaḥ khaladhūrttayoḥ //
analyzed: kañcukaḥ vāra vāṇe syāt nirmmoke kavace pi  varddhāpaka gṛhīta aṅga sthita vastre ca colake  auṣadhau kañcukī ca atha vañcakaḥ khala dhūrttayoḥ
translated: Kañcuka is used for a varavāṇa, and for a nirmoka, and also for armor.🔽And for the cloth worn by the one who has taken the vow of increase, it is called cōlaka.🔽Kañcuki is used for medicine, and also for a deceiver, and for a wicked rogue.

analyzed: jambūke gṛha babhrau ca guhyakaḥ cheka nidhnayoḥ
translated: Guhyaka is used for a jackal, and for a house-wandering animal, and for a goblin, and for a deceitful person.

analyzed: bandhakaḥ syāt vinimaye puścalyā syāt ca bandhakī
translated: Bandhaka is used for exchange, and bandhakī is used for a prostitute.

analyzed: gāndhika lekhake prāhuḥ sugandhi vyavahāriṇi
translated: They say gāndhika is used for a writer, and for one engaged in fragrant transactions.

analyzed: granthika pippalī mūle granthika guggulu drume
translated: Granthika is used for the root of long pepper, and granthika is used for the guggula tree,

original: mādreye ca karīre ca daivajñe ca prakīrttitam // //
analyzed: mādreye ca karīre ca daivajñe ca prakīrttitam
translated: and for the madra plant, and for the karira fruit, and for an astrologer, it is well-known.

analyzed: vāhikaḥ dhīra hiṅgunoḥ
translated: Vāhika is used for a horse in a particular country, and vāhika is used for the dhīra and hiṅgu plants.

analyzed: anayoḥ api vāhlīlaḥ yājñikaḥ yājake kuśe
translated: Vāhlīka is used for both of these, and yājñika is used for a sacrificial priest and for kuśa grass.

analyzed: vārṣika trāyamāṇe syāt varpā kālabhavenya vat
translated: Vārṣika is used for trāyamāṇā, and for the rainy season, like any other.

analyzed: khaṅgikaḥ mahiṣī kṣīre phena saunikayoḥ api
translated: Khagika is also for a sword-bearer and the foam of buffalo milk.

original: āhnika dinanirvartye bhojane nityakarmaṇi //🔽guṇḍako maline dhūlau kaloktisnehapātrayoḥ // //
analyzed: āhnika dina nirvartye bhojane nityakarmaṇi  guṇḍakaḥ maline dhūlau kalā ukti sneha pātrayoḥ
translated: Ahnika is for daily duties and meals.🔽Gundaka is for dirty dust, and kalokti is for two vessels of oil.

analyzed: gaṇḍakaḥ khaḍgini khyātaḥ saṅkhaya avidyā prabhedayoḥ
translated: Gundaka is known for a sword-bearer, and for the divisions of arithmetic.

analyzed: avacchede intarāye ca gaṇḍakī sarit antare
translated: Gundaki is for an obstruction in the middle, and for another river.

analyzed: taṇḍakaḥ khañjane phene samāsa prāya vāci ca
translated: Tandaka is for a lame person, for foam, and for a word ending in a compound.

original: gṛhadārau taruṣkandhamāyābahulayorapi // //🔽kaṇṭakaḥ kṣudraśatrau ca karmmasthānakadoṣyoḥ //🔽romāñce ca drumāṅge ca kaṇṭako makare'pi ca // //
analyzed: gṛha dārau taruṣkandha māyā bahulayoḥ api  kaṇṭakaḥ kṣudra śatrau ca karmmasthānaka doṣyoḥ  romāñce ca druma aṅge ca kaṇṭakaḥ ca
translated: Taruska is for a house and wife, for the trunk of a tree, and for one with many illusions.🔽Kantaka is for a small enemy, for a place of action, and for a fault.🔽Kantaka is also for horripilation, for a tree limb, and for a crocodile.

analyzed: takṣakaḥ phaṇibhede ca barddhaki drumabhedayoḥ
translated: Takshaka is for a kind of serpent, and for a carpenter and a kind of tree.

original: pakṣakaḥ pārśvamātre ca pakṣadvāre ca pakṣakaḥ // //🔽śaṅkhaka balaye kambau śiroroge ca śaṅkhakaḥ //
analyzed: pakṣakaḥ pārśva mātre ca pakṣa dvāre ca pakṣakaḥ  śaṅkhaka balaye kambau śiraḥ roge ca śaṅkhakaḥ
translated: Pakshaka is for the side only, and for a door with wings.🔽Shankhaka is for strength, for a conch, and for a disease of the head.

analyzed: nandakaḥ hari khaḍge syāt harṣake kulapālake  /
translated: Nandaka is for a yellow sword, for joy, and for a family protector.

analyzed: śītakaḥ śīta kāle ca susthite dīrghasūtriṇi
translated: Shitaka is for the cold season, for one well-established, and for a procrastinator.

original: uṣṇakastu nidāghe syāddāture kṣiprakāriṇi // //🔽ducchako gandhakuṭayā syādvihārābhyavakāśayoḥ //
analyzed: uṣṇakaḥ tu nidāghe syāt dāture kṣiprakāriṇi  ducchakaḥ gandhakuṭayā syāt vihāra abhyavakāśayoḥ
translated: Uṣṇaka is used for a hot season, and for a donor who acts quickly.🔽Ducchaka is used for a fragrant chamber, and for the open space in a monastery.

analyzed: dundukaḥ śoṇake krūre kṣullakaḥ su alpa nīcayoḥ  /
translated: Dunduka is used for a reddish-brown color, and for a small and low thing.

analyzed: piṣṭakaḥ netra roge syāt dhānya ādi camase pi ca
translated: Piṣṭaka is used for an eye disease, and also for a vessel made of grain, etc.

analyzed: bhasmaka roga bhede syāt viḍaṅga kaladhautayoḥ
translated: Bhasmaka is used for a type of disease, and for viḍaṅga and mercury.

analyzed: tumbakaḥ syāt bahu guru dhūrtta ayaskānta kāmuke
translated: Tuṃbaka is used for many, heavy, deceitful, magnetic, and for one who is passionate.

analyzed: jambukaḥ śvāpade nīce pratīcī dikpatau api
translated: Jaṃbūka is used for an animal, for a low person, and for the western direction.

analyzed: kārmmuka vaśa dhanuṣoḥ karmma śakte tu vācya vat
translated: Kārmmuka is used for a bow that can be bent, and for action and power, like a word.

analyzed: nirmmokaḥ mokṣake vyomni sannāhe sarpa kañcuke
translated: Nirmmāka is used for liberation, for the sky, for a cloud, and for a snake's slough.

original: ruḍukko vādyabhede syāddātyūhe madamattake //🔽turuṣkaḥ sihlake mlecchajātau śrīvāsake kkacit // //
analyzed: ruḍukkaḥ vādya bhede syāt dātyūhe mada mattake  turuṣkaḥ sihlake mleccha jātau śrīvāsake kkacid
translated: Ruḍuk is used for a type of musical instrument, and for a partridge, and for one who is intoxicated with pride.🔽Turṣka is used for a type of perfume, for a barbarian tribe, and for Śrīvāsa in some places.

original: ikṣvākuḥ kaṭutumbyāñca sūryyavaśanṛpe'pi ca //🔽kuṇṭhākuśca durādharpe duḥśīle ca bileśaye // //
analyzed: ikṣvākuḥ kaṭutumbyām ca sūryyavaśa nṛpe pi ca  kuṇṭhākuḥ ca durādharpe duḥśīle ca bileśaye
translated: Ikṣvāku is used for a bitter gourd, and for a king who is like the sun.🔽Kuṇṭhāku is used for one who is difficult to subdue, for one who is of bad character, and for one who lives in a hole.

analyzed: kuṣākuḥ markaṭe bhānau para uttāpini pāvake
translated: Kuṣāku is used for a monkey, for the sun, and for a fire that burns intensely.

analyzed: pṛdākuḥ vṛścike vyāghre citrake ca sarīsṛpe
translated: Pṛdāku is used for a crocodile, scorpion, tiger, a variegated animal, and a reptile.

analyzed: sṛdākuḥ anile vajre dāva agnau pratisūryyake
translated: Sṛdāku is used for wind, thunderbolt, forest fire, and a secondary sun.

analyzed: guraṅkuḥ pakṣi jātau ca bhavet nagnaka vandinoḥ  /
translated: Guraṅku is used for a bird, and for the two, Nagnaka and Vandin.

analyzed: triśaṅkuḥ śalabhe rāja viśeṣe vṛṣa daśake
translated: Triśaṅku is used for a grasshopper, a particular king, and a group of ten bulls.

analyzed: palyaṅkaḥ mañca paryyaṅka vṛṣī paryastikāsu ca
translated: Palyaṅka is used for a couch, a bed, a bull, and a pillow.

original: karaṅko mastake śasyanārikelaphalāsthini //🔽kalaṅko'ṅke'pavāde ca kālāyasamale'pi ca // //
analyzed: karaṅkaḥ mastake śasya nārikela phala asthini  kalaṅka uṅkepa vāde ca kālāyasam alepi ca
translated: Karaṅka is used for the head, a grain, and the shell of a coconut fruit.🔽Kalaka is used for a mark, a censure, and black iron ore.

analyzed: bhālāṅkaḥ karapatre syāt śākabhede ca rohite
translated: Bhālakaṅka is used for a sword, and for a kind of vegetable and a red fish.

original: mahālakṣaṇasampannapuruṣe kacchape hare // //🔽vṛṣāṅkaḥ śaṅkare sādhau bhallātakamahokṣayoḥ //
analyzed: mahā lakṣaṇa sampanna puruṣe kacchape hare  vṛṣāṅkaḥ śaṅkare sādhau bhallātaka mahokṣayoḥ
translated: Mahālakṣaṇa is used for a man endowed with great marks, and for a tortoise.🔽Vṛṣāṅka is used for Śaṅkara, a good person, and for a bhallātaka and a big bull.

analyzed: mṛgāṅkaḥ mārute candre stabakaḥ śubhra gucchayoḥ  /
translated: Mṛgāṅka is used for the wind, the moon, and for a bunch of white flowers.

analyzed: ātaṅkaḥ roga santāpa śaṅkāsu muraja dhvanau  pālaṅkaḥ śallakī śāka bhedayoḥ prāji pakṣiṇi  /
translated: Ātaṅka is used for a disease, a distress, a doubt, and for the sound of a Mura drum.🔽Pālakaṅka is used for a kind of vegetable, and for a bird with webbed feet.
Alarka is used for a white sun, and for a dog in a state of possession.

analyzed: udarke eṣyat kālīye phale madanakaṇṭake  /
translated: Udarka is used for a fruit that will ripen in the future, and for a Madana plant.

analyzed: samparkaḥ vitarkaḥ
translated: Samparka is used for contact between two separate things, and Vitaraka for doubt between two things with uncertainty.

analyzed: ambikā pārvatī pāṇḍu jananyoḥ api mātari  /
translated: Ambika is used for both the mother of Parvati and the mother of Pandu.

analyzed: andhikā kaitave miśre sarṣapyām api kīrtyate
translated: Andhika is used for deceit and mixture, and is also mentioned for mustard.

analyzed: amlikā tantriḍīka amlodgāra cāṅgerikāsu ca
translated: Amlika is used for tamarind, sourness, belching, and red chalk.

analyzed: yūthikāmlānake puṣpa viśeṣe api ca yūthikā
translated: Yuthika is used for a kind of sour flower, and also for a particular flower.

original: rājikāpi ca kedāre rājasarṣaparekhayoḥ // //🔽rasikāpi rasālāyā kāñcīrasanayorapi //
analyzed: rājikā api ca kedāre rāja sarṣapa rekhayoḥ  rasikā api kāñcī rasanayoḥ api
translated: Rajika is used for a kind of grain, for the line of a royal mustard, and for a kind of grain.🔽Rasika is used for a kind of sweetmeat, for a necklace, and for a kind of sweetmeat.

analyzed: ruṇḍikā dūtikāyāḥ raṇa kṣitau
translated: Rundika is used for a kind of door-bolt, and for a female messenger on the battlefield.

analyzed: bhūmikā syāt mūrti antara parigrahe  karṇikā kari hasta agre kara madhya aṅgulau api
translated: Bhumika is used for a composition, and for the adoption of another form.🔽Karnika is used for the tip of an elephant's trunk, and for the middle finger of a hand.

analyzed: kramuka ādi chaṭā āśe ca karṇikā karṇabhūṣaṇe
translated: Kramuka is used for a kind of flower, and Karnika is used for an ornament worn on the ear.

analyzed: bījakośe sarojasya kuṭṭanyām api kutracid
translated: In some places, Karnika is used for the seed-vessel of a lotus, and for a prostitute.

analyzed: karṇikā sūkṣma vastu agni manthayoḥ  gaṇikāḥ yūthikā veśyā tarkārī kariṇīṣu ca
translated: Karnika is said to be used for a very small thing, and for a kind of plant.🔽Ganika is used for a group, for a prostitute, for a kind of plant, and for an elephant.

analyzed: ca daiva jñe kārikā naṭa yoṣiti
translated: Ganaka is used for a group, for an astrologer, and for a female dancer.

analyzed: kṛtau vivaraṇa śloke yātanāyām ca kārikā
translated: In the two verses of the commentary, and in the torture, there is kārikā.

analyzed: nāpita ādika śilpe pi jālikā jālinī phale
translated: In the craft of a barber, etc., there is jālikā in the fruit of jālinī.

analyzed: bhaṭānām aśma racita aṅgarakṣiṇyām ca jālikā
translated: In the protection of the body made of stone of the soldiers, there is also jālikā.

analyzed: girisāre jalaukāyām api syāt vidhavā striyām
translated: In the water-leech, and in the widow woman, there is also giriśāra.

analyzed: jālikāḥ punar uddiṣṭaḥ grāmakūṭe ca dhīvare
translated: Jālikā is again mentioned in the village-trick and in the fisherman.

analyzed: nīlikaā nīlinī kṣudraroga śephālikāsu api
translated: In the blue-liṅga, in the small disease of the sugar-cane, and in the śephālikā, there is nīlikā.

original: kālikā yoginībhede kārṣṇye gauryyā dhanāvalau // //🔽kramadeye vastumūlye bhūsarīnavameghayoḥ //
analyzed: kālikā yoginī bhede kārṣṇye gauryyāḥ dhanāvalau  krama deye vastu mūlye bhūsarī nava meghayoḥ
translated: Kālikā is in the division of the Yoginīs, in the blackness, in the wealth of Gaurī.🔽In the price of a thing to be given in succession, in the earth, and in the new cloud, there is kālikā.

analyzed: paṭola śākhā romālī māsīkākīṣu kālikā
translated: In the branch of the bottle-gourd, in the hair-garland, in the māsikā, and in the kiṣu, there is kālikā.

analyzed: tathā vṛścika patre pi mālikā sarit antare
translated: Similarly, in the scorpion leaf, there is mālīkā in the river.

original: graiveye puṣpamālāyā pakṣimalle ca mālikā // //🔽bālikā bālukābālāpiccholākarṇabhūṣaṇe //
analyzed: graiveye puṣpa mālāyāḥ pakṣi malle ca mālikā
translated: In the necklace, in the flower garland, and in the bird-wrestler, there is mālīkā.🔽Bālikā is said in the sand, in the young one, in the peacock's feather, and in the ear ornament.

original: tūlikā kathitā lekhyakūrccikātūlaśayyayoḥ // //🔽cūlikā nāṭakasyā'ṅge karṇamūle ca dantināt //
analyzed: tūlikā kathitā lekhya kūrccikā tūla śayyayoḥ  cūlikā nāṭakasya aṅge karṇa mūle ca
translated: Tūlikā is said in the writing, in the short, and in the cotton bed.🔽Cūlikā is in the part of the drama, and in the ear of the elephant.

analyzed: mallikā tṛṇa śūnye api mīna mṛd pātra bhedayoḥ
translated: Mallikā is in the grass-less, and in the two kinds of fish and clay vessels.

analyzed: lallikaḥ hasa bhede syāt jhillikā jhilikā api ca
translated: Lallika is used in the sense of a kind of dance and a kind of laughter. Jhilikā is also used in the same sense.

analyzed: vilepane male jhillyām ātapasya ruci smṛtā
translated: Jhilikā is used in the sense of smearing and dirt. Ruci is used in the sense of sunlight.

original: vālukā sikatāsu syādvālukantvailavāluke //🔽nagnikā tu kumāryyā syādatha kṣapaṇavandinoḥ // //🔽nagnako dhenukādhenau strīkareṇvoḥ prasūtayoḥ //
analyzed: vālukā sikatāsu syāt vālukantu ailavāluke  nagnikā tu kumāryyā syāt atha kṣapaṇa vandinoḥ  / nagnakaḥ dhenukā dhenau strī kareṇvoḥ prasūtayoḥ
translated: Vāluka is used in the sense of sand. Ailvāluka is used in the sense of a kind of sand.🔽Nagnikā is used in the sense of a young unmarried girl. Kṣapaṇa and vadin are used in the sense of a naked ascetic.🔽Nagaka is used in the sense of a cow and a bull. Karṇva is used in the sense of the two kinds of cows.

original: reṇukāpi hareṇau syājjāmadagnistriyāmapi // //🔽jatukā jinapatrāyā jatuka hiṅgulākṣayoḥ //
analyzed: reṇukā api hareṇau syāt jāmadagni striyām api  jatukā jinapatrāyāḥ hiṅgu lākṣayoḥ
translated: Reṇukā is used in the sense of a kind of sand and a woman of the son of Jamadagni.🔽Jatuka is used in the sense of a kind of grass and a kind of asafoetida.

analyzed: kūrccikā sūcikāyām ca tūlikāyām ca kuḍmale
translated: Kūrcchikā is used in the sense of a needle and a kind of cotton.

analyzed: kavāṭa kuṭṭake kṣīra vikṛtau api kūrccikā
translated: Kūrcchikā is also used in the sense of a door-panel and a kind of milk-preparation.

analyzed: mātṛkā dhātrikā mātroḥ mātrika karaṇa imbare  /
translated: Mātṛkā is used in the sense of a nurse and a kind of measure. Mātrikā is used in the sense of a musical instrument and the sky.

analyzed: patākāḥ vaijayantyām ca saubhāgya iṅke dhvaje pi ca
translated: Patākā is used in the sense of a banner and good fortune. Aṅka is used in the sense of a flag and a mark.

original: syāt putrikā puttalikā duhitroryāvatūlike // //🔽putrakaḥ śarabhe dhūrtte śailavṛkṣaprabhedayoḥ //
analyzed: syāt putrikā puttalikā duhitroḥ yāvatūlike  / putrakaḥ śarabhe dhūrtte śaila vṛkṣa prabhedayoḥ
translated: Putrikā is used in the sense of a doll and a daughter. Yāvat is used in the sense of a kind of cotton.🔽Puttaka is used in the sense of a kind of antelope, a rogue, and a kind of mountain and tree.

analyzed: uṣṭrikā mṛttikā bhāṇḍa bhede pi karabhastriyām
translated: Karabha is used in the sense of a kind of earthen pot and a female camel.
Diṃbikā is used in the sense of a kind of water-nimba and a kind of lover.

analyzed: kāmikā nīlikāyām ca syamīkaḥ nāku vṛkṣayoḥ
translated: Kāmikā is used for Nīlikā, and Syamaika for Nāku and Vṛkṣa trees.

analyzed: dūṣikā tūlikāyām ca dūṣikā netrayoḥ male
translated: Dūṣikā is used for Tūlikā, and Dūṣikā for the impurities in the eyes.

analyzed: ūrmmikā ca aṅgulīye syāt vastrabhaṅga taraṅgayoḥ  /
translated: Ūrmikā is used for Aṅgulīya, and Vastra-bhaṅga for Taruṅga.

analyzed: tathā udbāhulake api syāt ūrmmikā madhupa dhvanau
translated: Ūrmikā is also used for Udbāhu, and Madhu-dhvani.

analyzed: syāt śalākā api madana śārikā śalyayoḥ śalā  /
translated: Śalākā is used for Madana, Śārikā, and Śalya.

analyzed: chatra pañjara kāṣṭhayām ca śallakī paśu vṛkṣayoḥ
translated: Śallikā is used for Chatra, Pañjara, and Kāṣṭha, and for the animals and trees.

analyzed: narttakī lāsikāyām ca kareṇvām api narttakī
translated: Narttakī is used for Lāsakā, and Kareṇvī for Narttakī.

analyzed: narttakaḥ kelake poṭagala cāraṇayoḥ naṭe
translated: Nartaka is used for Kelaka, and Potala for Cāraṇa and Naṭa.

analyzed: culukī kuṇḍībhede kulāntake
translated: Culuka is used for Śiśumāra, and Kuṇḍī for Bhaeda and Kula-antaka.

analyzed: catuṣkī maśake haryyā catuṣkī yaṣṭikā antare
translated: Caturkī is used for Maśaka, and Harya for Caturkī and Yaṣṭika.

analyzed: ka catuṣkam
translated: Kacaturka.

analyzed: amimakaḥ pike bheke madhuke padma kesare  /
translated: Amimika is used for Pika, Bheka, Madhuka, and Padma-keshara.

analyzed: bhavet alipakaḥ bhṛṅge kokile rathahiṇḍake
translated: Aliptaka is used for Bhṛṅga, Kokila, and Ratha-hiṇḍaka.

analyzed: smṛtaḥ kuravakaḥ śoṇa amlāna jhiṇṭī prabhedayoḥ
translated: Kuruvaka is remembered for the varieties of Śoṇā, Āmlāna, and Jhiṇṭī.

analyzed: bhavet maruvakaḥ puṣpa viśeṣe madana drume
translated: Maruvaka is used for a particular flower and Madana tree.

analyzed: valāhakaḥ girau meghe daitya nāga viśeṣayoḥ
translated: Vālāhaka is used for Giri, Megha, Daitya, and Nāga.
Bhramara is used for a bee in water, and for Girisha's powdered hair.
Varataka is used for a thick rope, a lotus seed, and a Kapardika.

analyzed: śṛṅgāṭaka bhavet vārikaṇṭake ca catuṣpathe
translated: Shringataka is used for a water thorn and a crossroads.

original: gokaṇṭako gokṣurake sthapuṭe ca gavā khure // //🔽ākalpakastamomohagranthīpūtkalikāmudoḥ //
analyzed: gokaṇṭakaḥ gokṣurake sthapuṭe ca gavā khure  / ākalpakaḥ tamaḥ moha granthī pūt kalikā mudoḥ
translated: Gokantuka is used for a cow's thorn, a cow's hoof, and a cow's urine.🔽Akalkaka is used for the knots of darkness, delusion, and the sprouts of joy.

analyzed: ākṣepaka unila vyādhau vyādhe nindā kare pi ca
translated: Akshepaka is used for a wind disease and for a disease that is also criticized.

original: pracalākaḥ śarāghāte dandaśūke bhujaṅgame //🔽vṛndārakaḥ sure śreṣṭhe manojñe punaranyavat // //
analyzed: pracalākaḥ śara āghāte dandaśūke bhujaṅgame  vṛndārakaḥ sure śreṣṭhe manojñe punar anya vat
translated: Prachalaka is used for a shaft wound and for a snake with fangs.🔽Vridaraka is used for a god, for the best, and for something pleasant, but in another way.

original: niyāmakaḥ karṇadhāre potavāhe niyantari //🔽vināyakastu herambe tārkṣye vijñe jine gurau // //
analyzed: niyāmakaḥ karṇadhāre pota vāhe niyantari  vināyakaḥ tu herambe tārkṣye vijñe jine gurau
translated: Niyamik is used for an earring, a boatman, and a controller.🔽Vinayaka is used for Hera, and Tarkshya should be known as Jina and Guru.

analyzed: niścārakaḥ puriṣasya kṣaye svaire samīraṇe
translated: Nishcharaka is used for the waste of feces, for a private wind, and for a free wind.

analyzed: bhaṭṭārakaḥ sure rājñi kathitaḥ ca tapodhane
translated: Bhattaraka is used for a god, a king, and for one who has austerities.

original: dāserakaḥ syāt karabhe dāsīputre ca dhīvare //🔽aṅgāraka kuje vidyādulmukāśe kuruṇṭake // //
analyzed: dāserakaḥ syāt karabhe dāsī putre ca dhīvare  aṅgāraka kuje vidyāt ulmuka āśe kuruṇṭake  /
translated: Daseruka is used for a camel, for the son of a female servant, and for a fisherman.🔽Angaraka should be known as Mars, and Ulmukasha is used for a Kurunta.

analyzed: aṅgārikā ikṣukāṇḍe syāt korake kiśukasya ca
translated: Angari is used for a sugarcane stalk and for a seed of the Kishu fruit.

analyzed: dalāḍhakaḥ tu kunde syāt karikarṇa śirīpayoḥ
translated: Dalaḍhaka is used for jasmine, and karīkarṇa for śirīṣa.

analyzed: svayañjāta tile phene khātake nāgakeśare
translated: Svayaṃjāta is used for sesame, phena for foam, and khātaka for saffron.

analyzed: vātyāyāḥ praśnikāyāḥ ca gairike ca mahattare
translated: Vātyā is used for prṣṇikā and mahantara for red chalk.

analyzed: bhavet pūrṇānaka pūrṇapātre paṭaha pātrayoḥ
translated: Pūrṇā is used for a full vessel and paṭaha for a kind of drum.

original: prakīrṇaka granthabhede cāmare vistare haye // //🔽smṛtaḥ puṣkalako gandhamṛge kṣapaṇakīlayoḥ //
analyzed: prakīrṇaka granthabhede cāmare vistare haye  / smṛtaḥ puṣkalakaḥ gandhamṛge kṣapaṇa kīlayoḥ
translated: Prakīrṇaka is used for a type of text, and cāmara for a fan.🔽Puṣkalaka is used for musk and kṣapaṇakī for a kind of play.

analyzed: kośātakaḥ kace jyautsni paṭolī ghoṣakeṣu tu
translated: Kośātaka is used for a lock of hair, and jyotiṣpaṭola for a kind of gourd.

analyzed: kośātakī vāṇijake vāḍabāgnau vaṇijī api
translated: Kośātakī is used for a kind of grain, and vāḍavāgni for a submarine fire.

analyzed: nirgranthakaḥ syāt kṣapaṇe
translated: Nirgranthaka is used for a Jaina ascetic, and niṣphala for a fruitless garment.

analyzed: syāt aśmantakam uddhāne mālukā chadane api ca
translated: Aśmantaka is used for a kind of stone, and mālukā for a kind of cloth.

original: kaṭillakastu parṇāse varṣābhūkāravellayoḥ //🔽kaparddako varāṭe syājjaṭājūṭe'pi dhūrjjaṭeḥ //
analyzed: kaṭillakaḥ tu varṣābhū kāravellayoḥ  kaparddakaḥ varāṭe syāt jaṭājūṭe api dhūrjjaṭeḥ
translated: Kaṭillaka is used for a kind of grass, and varṣābhū for a kind of creeper.🔽Kaparddaka is used for a lock of hair, and dhūrjjati for a kind of grass.

analyzed: kākole patrake api ca
translated: Gomeḍaka is used for a yellow gem, and kākola for a kind of leaf.

analyzed: maṇḍodakaḥ citrarāge bhavet ātarpaṇe api ca
translated: Maṇḍodaka is used for a kind of dye, and ātarppaṇa for a kind of offering.

analyzed: śatānīkaḥ muneḥ bhede vṛddhe
translated: Śatānīka is used for a kind of sage, and vṛddha for a kind of donkey.

analyzed: grāmaṇīḥ bhāṇḍa bhārāva upadhāneṣu prayujyate
translated: The word grāmāṇi is used for the head of a village, the sound of a load, and a kind of couch.

analyzed: lekhanikaḥ lekhahāre yaḥ vilekhayet
translated: The one who writes with his own hand in a letter is called a lekhanika.

original: lekheṣu parahastena tatrāpyeṣa pradarśitaḥ //🔽bhavenmaṇḍalaka bimbe kuṣṭhabhede ca darpaṇe // //
analyzed: lekheṣu para hastena tatra api eṣa pradarśitaḥ  bhavet maṇḍalaka bimbe kuṣṭha bhede ca darpaṇe
translated: This is also shown in letters written by another's hand.🔽The word maṇḍalaka is used for a circle, an image, a kind of leprosy, and a mirror.
The word pippalaka is used for the nipple of a breast, and for a thread used in sewing.

analyzed: pīṇḍītakaḥ syāt tagare madanadrau phaṇijyake
translated: The word piṇḍītaka is used for a kind of sugar, and for the two trees Madana and Phāṇijya.

analyzed: gokṣurake triphalāyāḥ kaṭutrike
translated: The word trivarṇaka is used for the three roots, for the three myrobalans, and for the three pungent substances.

analyzed: śālāvṛkaḥ śṛgāle ipi sārameye valīmukhe
translated: The word śālāvrka is used for a jackal, and for a dog with grey hair on the face.

analyzed: kauleyakaḥ kula śreṣṭhe syāt indra maha kāmuke
translated: The word kauleya is used for the best of the family, and for Indra and Kama.
The word suprati is used for a beautiful limb, and for the elephant in the northeast direction.

analyzed: jaivātṛkaḥ kṛśe candre bhaiṣajya āyuṣmatoḥ api
translated: The word jīvātṛka is used for a thin moon, and for medicine and longevity.

original: ratarddhika syāddivase sukhasnāne'ṣṭamaṅgale // //🔽vaināśikaḥ syāt kṣaṇike paratantorṇanābhayoḥ //
analyzed: ratarddhika syāt divase sukha snāna iṣṭa maṅgale  / vaināśikaḥ syāt kṣaṇike para tantu ūrṇanābhayoḥ
translated: The word ratarddhi is used for the day, for a pleasant bath, and for the eight auspicious things.🔽The word vaināśika is used for the momentary, and for the dependent and the cotton-maker.

analyzed: vaidehakaḥ vāṇijake śūdrāt vaiśyā sute pi ca
translated: The word vaidehaka is used for a merchant, and for a son born to a Śūdra from a Vaiśya woman.

analyzed: vitunnakam tu dhanyāke tathā jhāṇṭā amalauṣadhau
translated: The word vitunnaka is used for the blessed, and for the herbs Jhaṇṭā and Amalaka.

analyzed: gokuṇikaḥ kekare syāt paṅka sthe gavi upekṣake  /
translated: Gokuni is used for a squint-eyed person, and gavyupeksaka for one who neglects cows in mud.

analyzed: bhāryāṭikaḥ bhavet bhāryā nirjjite hariṇa antare
translated: Bharyatika is used for a wife, and harinantarajita for a deer.

analyzed: chātrasya akādaśa āsini
translated: Kapaṭika is used for one who knows the weak points of others, and ākāśāsin for a student.

analyzed: kaukkuṭikaḥ dāmbhike syāt adūra prerita īkṣaṇe
translated: Kaukkuṭika is used for a hypocrite, and adūrapre-ritakṣaṇa for one who casts his eyes not far.

analyzed: lālāṭikaḥ prabhoḥ bhāva darśinī āśleṣaṇa antare
translated: Lālāṭika is used for one who sees the feelings of his master, and śleṣaṇāntara for one who is embraced.

analyzed: śilāṭakaḥ śilāṭṭayoḥ
translated: Śilāṭaka is used for one who is considered incapable of work, and śilāṭṭa for two stones.

analyzed: karkkoṭakaḥ syāt mālūra kādraveya prabhedayoḥ
translated: Karkkoṭaka is used for two kinds of trees, mālūra and kādrava.

analyzed: varaṇṭakaḥ tu mātaṅgvaidyāḥ yauvanakaṇṭake
translated: Varanṭaka is used for two kinds of trees, mātaṅgva and yauvanakaṇṭaka.

analyzed: sa varttulepya ākhanikaḥ caure kroḍe ca mūṣake
translated: Ākhani is used for a thief, and kroḍa for a rat.

analyzed: vaitālikaḥ bodha kare kheṭita ālepī udīritaḥ
translated: Vaitālika is used for one who wakes others up, and kheṭitāla for a kind of musical time.

analyzed: tiktaśākaḥ tu khadire varuṇe patrasundare
translated: Tiktaśāka is used for two kinds of trees, khadira and varuṇa, and patrasuṃdara for one with beautiful leaves.

original: mayūrako'pyapāmārge tucchake tu mayūrakam //🔽viśeṣakaḥ syāttilake viśeṣāvāhake'pi ca // //
analyzed: mayūraka upī apāmārge tucchake tu mayūrakam  viśeṣakaḥ syāt tilake viśeṣa āvāhake api ca
translated: Mayūraka is used for two kinds of trees, apāmārga and tucchaka.🔽Viśeṣaka is used for two kinds of trees, tilaka and viśeṣāvāhaka.

analyzed: vidṛṣakaḥ cāṭu paṭau para nindā karepi ca
translated: Vidṛṣaka is used for two kinds of trees, āṭu and paṭa, and paraniṃdākara for one who censures others.

analyzed: bhavet
translated: Saikatika is used for two kinds of trees, mātṛ and yātrāmaṅgala.

analyzed: tathā sa nyasta sandeha jīva kṣepaṇakeṣu api
translated: Similarly, in the case of Sannyasa, Sankshepa, and Jiva-khepanaka.

analyzed: eḍamūkaḥ smṛtaḥ dhīraiḥ śaṭhe vāc śruti varjjite
translated: The wise consider a dumb sheep as a coward, and a mute as devoid of speech and hearing.

analyzed: varttarūkaḥ nadī bhede kākanīle jalāvaṭe
translated: Varta-ruka is a kind of river, and ka-ka-nila is a water-hole.

analyzed: kākarūkaḥ ulṛke syāt niḥsve strī jita dambhayoḥ  /
translated: Ka-ka-ruka is a kind of bird, and u-lu-ruka is a kind of owl. Ni-sva is used for a poor person, and for a woman-dominated person.

analyzed: digambare bhīruke ca dandaśū kohirakṣamoḥ
translated: Dig-ambara is used for a naked person, and for a coward. Dan-da-shuka is used for a snake, and for a protector.

analyzed: muṣṭerukaḥ vadānye pi miṣṭa āśini atithi dvipi
translated: Mush-ta-ruka is used for a generous person, and for a guest. Mish-ta-ashini is used for a sweet-eater.

analyzed: kṛkavākuḥ mayūre pi saraṭe caraṇāyudhe
translated: Krik-a-vakuk is used for a peacock, and for a bird with feet as weapons.

original: missing page kaṣaṭkam //🔽lūtāmarkkaṭakaḥ putryā navamālyā plavaṅgame //
analyzed: missing page  lūtāmarkkaṭakaḥ putryā navamālyā plavaṅgame
translated: The Kashtaka group.🔽Luta-marka-taka is used for a son, and for a garland of flowers. Pla-vangama is used for a monkey.

analyzed: sindūratilakaḥ nāge sindūratilakā striyām
translated: Sindhu-ra-tilaka is used for a serpent, and for a woman with vermilion mark.

analyzed: varṇa viloḍakaḥ śloke chāyā hāriṇi kumbhile
translated: Varna-vila-odaka is used for a verse, and for a pumpkin that steals the shadow.
Matula-putraka is used for a clever person, and for the son of one's maternal uncle.

analyzed: grāmamadgurikā śṛṅyā grāma yuddhe ca kīrttyate
translated: Grama-madguraka is used for a kind of deer, and for a village fight.

analyzed: syāt madana śalākā api śāryyā kāmoda yoṣadhau
translated: Madana-shala-aka is used for a kind of arrow, and for a plant that produces love.

analyzed: iti kānta vargaḥ
translated: Thus ends the group of words beginning with ka.

analyzed: kha ekakam
translated: The Ekaka group.

original: khamindriye sukhe svarge śūnye bindau vihāyasi //
analyzed: kham indriye sukhe svarge śūnye bindau vihāyasi
translated: Kham is used for a sense organ, for happiness, for heaven, for emptiness, for a dot, and for the sky.

analyzed: pure sa vedane kṣetre kulāhala phale kkacid
translated: In the city, in the field, in the fruit of the kulahala tree, somewhere.

analyzed: khadvikam
translated: The Khaduvikam (group of three).

original: nakhaḥ kararuhe śaṇḍe gandhadravye nakha nakhī //
analyzed: nakhaḥ kararuhe śaṇḍe gandha dravye
translated: Nakha means fingernail, a kind of grass, and a fragrant substance. Nakhi means a fingernail.

analyzed: mukha niḥsaraṇe vaktre prārambha upāyayoḥ api
translated: Mukha means the face, the outlet, and also the means of commencement.

original: sukha śarmaṇi nāke ca sukhā puryā pracetasaḥ //🔽śaṅkho nidhyantare kambulalāṭāsthinakhīṣu ca // //
analyzed: sukha śarmaṇi nāke ca sukhā puryā pracetasaḥ  śaṅkhaḥ nidhi antare kambu lalāṭa asthi nakhīṣu ca
translated: Sukha means happiness, heaven, and the city of the Pracetasas.🔽Sankha means the navel, a kind of conch, and the bone on the forehead. Nakhi means a fingernail.

analyzed: rekhā syāt alpake chadminyā ambhoga ullekhayoḥ api
translated: Lekha means a line, a little, a disguise, and also in the sense of enjoyment and writing.

analyzed: lekhā lekhye sure lekhā lipi rājikayoḥ matā
translated: Lekha means writing, a goddess, and is considered in the sense of writing and royal edict.

original: mukhaḥ samyagmanojñe'pi sāmnaḥ ṣaṭpraṇayeṣvapi // //🔽śikhā śiphāyā cūḍāyā jvālāyāmagramātrake //
analyzed: mukhaḥ samyak manojñe pi sāmnaḥ ṣaṣ praṇayeṣu api  śikhā śiphāyāḥ cūḍāyāḥ jvālāyām agra mātrake
translated: Mukha means complete, beautiful, and also in the sense of the six kinds of affection in music.🔽Shikha means a tuft of hair, a spike, a crest, and a flame, in the sense of the tip.

original: lāṅgalyāścāpi śākhāyā cūḍāyāñca śikhaṇḍinaḥ // //🔽sakhā mitre sahāye ca śākhāpakṣāntare bhuje //
analyzed: lāṅgalyāḥ ca api śākhāyāḥ cūḍāyām ca śikhaṇḍinaḥ  sakhā mitre sahāye ca śākhā pakṣa antare bhuje
translated: Shikhandi means a peacock, a tuft of hair, a crest, and also a spike.🔽Shakha means a friend, an assistant, and also in the sense of a branch and a wing.

analyzed: śākhā veda vibhāge ca ca
translated: Shakha means a branch of the Vedas, a part of the body, and also in the sense of near.

analyzed: preṅkhā paryaṭane nṛtye bhavet aśva gatau api
translated: Prengkha means wandering, dancing, and also in the sense of the gait of a horse.

analyzed: khaṅkhāḥ gati viśeṣe api śūkaśimbyām ca narttane  /
translated: Khangkha means a particular gait, and also in the sense of a kind of grass and dancing.

analyzed: khatrikam
translated: The Khatrikam (group of three).

analyzed: triśikha śekhare vidyā strī lekhā rākṣasa antare
translated: Triśikha is the crest, the Vidyā, and the letter between a woman and a demon.

analyzed: sumukha tārkṣyatanaye phaṇibhede ca paṇḍite
translated: Sumukha is the son of Garuḍa, the distinction between serpents, and the learned one.

analyzed: durmukhaḥ mukhare vānara aśvayoḥ
translated: Durmukha is also the king of serpents, and Mukhara is the horse of the monkey.

analyzed: gomukha kuṭilāgāre vādya bhāṇḍe ca lepake
translated: Gomukha is in the crooked house, the musical instrument, and the plaster.

analyzed: pramukhaḥ prathame śreṣṭhe viśikhaḥ tomare śare
translated: Praमुख is the best in the first, and Viśikha is in the lance and arrow.

analyzed: rathyā khanitryā viśikhā nalikāyām api kkacid
translated: Rathiyā is in the spade, and Viśikha is also in the tube sometimes.

analyzed: viśākhaḥ tārake skande viśākha ṛṣau kaṭillake
translated: Viśākha is in the star, Skanda, and Viśākha is the constellation in the waist.

analyzed: mayūkhaḥ tviṣ kara jvāle vaiśākhaḥ rādha manthayoḥ
translated: Mayūkha is in the ray, flame, and Vaiśākha is in the month of Caitra and the churning of curd.

analyzed: kha catuṣkam
translated: The group of four Kha.

original: agnimukho dvije deve bhallāte citrake kkacit //
analyzed: agnimukhaḥ dvije deve bhallāte citrake kkacid
translated: Agniमुख is in the Brāhmaṇa, god, Bhallāta, and Citra sometimes.

analyzed: pañcanakhaḥ gaje kūrme śilīmukha ūli vāṇayoḥ  /
translated: Pañचनख is in the elephant, tortoise, and Śīlimukha is in the bee and the elephant.

analyzed: bhavet vyāghranakhaḥ kanda gandha dravya viśeṣayoḥ
translated: Vyagh्रनख would be in the bulb and a particular fragrant substance.

analyzed: mahāśaṅkhaḥ nara asthni syāt nidhi saṅkhayā prabhedayoḥ  / indulekhā amṛtā somalatā śaśi kalāsu ca
translated: Mahāśaṅkha would be in the bone of a man, and Niḍhiśaṅkhayā is the distinction of the types.🔽Indulekhā is in nectar, moon, creeper, and digit of the moon.
Śaśilekhā is in the part of the digit, and Bākuci is the difference in the round.
Agniśikhā is in the crest of a plough, and Agniśikha is considered in saffron.

original: vaddhaśikhā jaṭāyā syād bāle baddhaśikho mataḥ // //
analyzed: vaddhaśikhā syāt bāle baddhaśikhaḥ mataḥ
translated: Vaḍḍhaśikhā would be in matted hair, and a boy with a tied crest is considered to have Vaḍḍhaśikhā.

analyzed: kha pañcakam  syāt malina mukhaḥ prete golāṅgūle khala inale
translated: The five Khas.🔽Malinamukha is in a ghost, a goblin, a rogue, and a fire.

analyzed: atha śītamayūkhaḥ api śaśāṅka ghanasārayoḥ    sarvatomukham ākhyātam antarikṣe ca pāthasi
translated: Now, the cool-rayed one is also in the moon and the essence of clouds.🔽It is said to be Sarvatomukha in all directions, in the sky, and in water.

analyzed: vidhi kṣetrajña rudreṣu kathitaḥ sarvatomukhaḥ
translated: Sarvatomukha is said to be in the creator, the individual soul, and Rudra.

analyzed: iti kha anta vargaḥ
translated: Thus ends the section on KHA.

analyzed: gaikakam
translated: The single GA.

original: gauḥ svarge vṛṣabhe raśmau vajre candramasi smṛtaḥ //
analyzed: gauḥ svarge vṛṣabhe raśmau vajre candramasi smṛtaḥ
translated: GA is remembered in heaven, in a bull, in a ray, in a thunderbolt, and in the moon.

analyzed: arjjune netra diś bāṇa bhū vāc vāriṣu gauḥ matā
translated: GA is considered in Arjuna, in the eyes, in the directions, in arrows, in the earth, in speech, and in water.

analyzed: ga dvikam
translated: The two GAs.

analyzed: agaḥ śaile drume bhānau nagavat pvanāsane
translated: AGA is in a mountain, in a tree, in the sun, in a mountain, and in a seat.

original: khagaḥ sūryye grahe deve mārgaṇe ca vihaṅgame // //
analyzed: khagaḥ sūryye grahe deve mārgaṇe ca vihaṅgame
translated: KHA GA is in the sun, in a planet, in a god, and in an arrow, and in a bird.

analyzed: bhagam aiśvaryya māhātmya jñāna vairāgya yoniṣu
translated: BHA is in fortune, in lordship, in greatness, in knowledge, in detachment, and in the sources.
In fame, in valor, in effort, in desire, in Lakshmi, in Dharma, in the sun, and in liberation.

analyzed: ratha sīra aṅgayoḥ yugaḥ
translated: Yuga is in the four cubits, and in a chariot, and in a plough.

original: yuga kṛtādau yugale vṛddhināmauṣadhe'pi ca // //🔽mṛgaḥ paśau kuraṅge ca karinakṣatrabhedayoḥ //
analyzed: yuga kṛta ādau yugale ca  / mṛgaḥ paśau kuraṅge ca kari nakṣatra bhedayoḥ
translated: In the beginning of the yuga, the two herbs are called Vrddhi.🔽A deer is in an animal, a gazelle, and in the two types of asterisms.

analyzed: yācñāyāḥ mṛgayāyām ca mṛgī syāt vanitā antare
translated: In the case of begging and hunting, a female deer is in another woman.

original: bhṛguḥ śukre prapāte ca jamadagnau pinākini //
analyzed: bhṛguḥ śukre prapāte ca jamadagnau pinākini
translated: Bhrigu is in Shukra, in a waterfall, in Jamadagni, and in the wielder of the Pinaka.

analyzed: bhāge rūpa arddhake proktaḥ bhāgadheya ekadeśayoḥ
translated: In parts and in half of a form, it is said in the case of a part and a portion.

original: nāgantu sīsake raṅge strībandhe karaṇāntare //🔽nāgaḥ pannagamātaṅgakrūracāriṣu toyade // //
analyzed: nāgantu sīsake raṅge strībandhe karaṇa antare  nāgaḥ pannaga mātaṅga krūra cāriṣu toyade  /
